alerts.title: Visitors to Great Barrier Reef reminded to be SharkSmart
alerts.description: Visitors to the Great Barrier Reef islands and beaches reminded to be SharkSmart:
alerts.details:
Visitors to the Great Barrier Reef islands and beaches reminded to be SharkSmart:

  • Don't swim at dawn or dusk
  • Always swim in clear water (not in murky water, busy anchorages, estuary mouths or canals)
  • Don't throw food scraps or fish waste overboard or into the water from the beach (including in anchorages or where people are swimming)
  • Don't swim where fish are being cleaned
  • Swim, surf, snorkel or dive with a buddy.

For more information visit https://www.daf.qld.gov.au/sharksmart

alerts.title: Permanent fire prohibition on Teewah Beach
alerts.description: A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.
alerts.details:
A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.

This permanent fire prohibition was implemented to reduce the risk of bushfires, protect critical habitat of native wildlife, enhance visitor safety from campfire related injuries and reduce rubbish from non-combustible materials being burnt.

Fully enclosed cooking and heating appliances can still be used in camping areas that meet the below requirements.

  • The appliance must use gas or manufactured fuel (heat beads, briquettes). Manufactured fuel does not include timber or wood.
  • It must be used only for cooking and/or heating.
  • It must be a minimum of 20cm off the ground and more than 2m from flammable materials, which includes vegetation. 
  • It must not have the potential to generate airborne embers, or possibly ignite nearby ground fuels.
  • It must be fully self-contained (heat source enclosed and no exposed flame) and never left unattended when in use.
  • Appliances that are not fully self-contained, such as braziers, are not permitted.
  • All appliances, materials and burnt fuel must be removed from the recreation area on your departure.

On the spot fines of $774 can be issued to people who light fires during a fire prohibition.

Campfires are permitted at Poverty Point camping area and at nearby Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area unless in accordance with all local directions for that area.

For details on the difference between a Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) total fire ban and a QPWS fire prohibition and approved cooking appliances visit the DES Camp fires and cooking web page.

QPWS thanks you for your cooperation while we implement this management change.

alerts.title: North West Island declaration of Special Activity Area (Sharks)
alerts.description: A new Special Activity Area has been declared at North West Island, Capricornia Cays National Park in accordance with Section 128 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.
alerts.details:
A new Special Activity Area has been declared at North West Island, Capricornia Cays National Park in accordance with Section 128 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.

This applies to the area surrounding North West Island on North West Island Reef to reduce the risk of humans interacting with sharks. Within the special activity area shown on the map (https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/capricornia-cays/maps-resources)

You must not:

  • attract sharks by any means or methods to have a close interaction
  • process fish product
  • dump fish scraps
  • clean fish processing equipment.

Penalties may apply if you do any of these activities without prior permission or agreement under Section 132 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.

alerts.title: Dingo (Wongari) Seasonal Information - Mating Season
alerts.description: The likelihood of negative dingo-human interactions is greatest during dingo mating season, particularly during the Easter school holiday period when there are a high number of visitors on Kgari (Fraser Island).
alerts.details:
The likelihood of negative dingo-human interactions is greatest during dingo mating season, particularly during the Easter school holiday period when there are a high number of visitors on Kgari (Fraser Island).

Dingo mating season means:

  • Increased dingo activity and a higher chance of dingo-human interaction.
  • Dominance testing behaviour—often misinterpreted as ‘playing’.
  • Unpredictable behaviour.
  • More howling at night.
  • Last year’s pups being forced to find new territory to avoid more dominant dingoes, and to find their own food.

 

Visitors, tour operators and residents are advised to be dingo-safe! on K’gari. It is recommended that families with young children camp in fenced QPWS camping areas at Lake Boomanjin, Central Station, Dundubara, Waddy Point and eastern beach fenced areas (Wongai, One Tree Rocks, Cornwells, Eli), or at fenced private camping areas at Dilli Village or Cathedral Beach.

 

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • NEVER feed dingoes.
  • Always stay within arm’s reach of children, even small teenagers.
  • Walk in groups and carry a stick.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Camp in fenced areas when possible.
  • Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on a boat).
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.
  • Secure all rubbish, fish and bait.

 

Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@des.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest QPWS ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150 – mobile phone charges may apply. Take note of location, vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number and which ear.

 

For further information about wongari (dingoes) on K’gari (Fraser Island) please visit

https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

alerts.title: Camper Hygiene
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) reminds campers of the need to maintain high personal hygiene standards whilst camping in the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) reminds campers of the need to maintain high personal hygiene standards whilst camping in the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.

QPWS would like to remind all visitors to maintain high personal hygiene, including washing hands frequently with soap and water, particularly after visiting the toilet, when preparing food and before eating and after visiting waste disposal and water point sites.

For the health and wellbeing of our park visitors and staff, and to limit the spread of illness visitors are recommended to:

  • Wash hands often with soap and water, especially before preparing food, eating and after going to the toilet (viral and bacterial stomach illnesses are not prevented with alcohole-based sanitisers).
  • Ensure all campers have a personal towel for hand drying.
  • Cover your coughs and sneezes with your elbow or a tissue.
  • Ensure your campsite is located away from other tents.
  • Where possible, bring your own portable toilet.
  • Keep your rubbish secure and dispose in bins provided or take home.
  • Stay at home if you or any members of your group are unwell.
  • Keep a personal supply of drinking and washing water during your stay. 

Check Park Alerts regularly for updates on current park conditions.

alerts.title: Portable toilets mandatory for Teewah Beach camping zones
alerts.description: All campers staying within the Teewah Beach camping zones 1 to 7 must bring and use a portable toilet for the duration of their stay. A minimum of one portable toilet per camping permit holder is required.
alerts.details:
All campers staying within the Teewah Beach camping zones 1 to 7 must bring and use a portable toilet for the duration of their stay. A minimum of one portable toilet per camping permit holder is required.

Portable toilets must have a sealed waste holding tank and must be transportable and suitable for emptying into a portable toilet waste disposal facility. Bag and open bucket style toilets are not permitted. 

Disposal waste facilities are available for use by campers at the following locations:

  • Second cutting, Noosa North Shore.
  • Freshwater day-use area, (beach camper service bay).
  • Clarkson Drive, Rainbow Beach.

Note: This is a permanent management change for Teewah Beach. 

It is an offence to camp at Teewah Beach camping area without a portable toilet, penalties apply.

alerts.title: On water signage in Moreton Bay Marine Park
alerts.description: Moreton Bay Marine Park users are advised not to rely on the presence of signage to inform them of their location within the various zones of the marine park. Marine Park zones are defined solely by GPS boundary locations, and users must refer to Schedule 1 and 2 of the Marine Parks (Moreton Bay) Zoning Plan 2019 for precise boundary descriptions. There are reliable digital platforms which provide all-round coverage and information of all the zones and designated areas for users. eg. Electronic chart systems used on GPS chart plotters, electronic chart Apps used for navigation on smart devices, including Queensland Globe and the QLD Fisheries 2.0 App. Legacy advisory signs installed since 1997 are being progressively phased out and updating of the Moreton Bay Marine Park printed and web materials will continue to occur progressively.

alerts.title: Threatening dingo activity - Eli Creek, Waddy Point and Wathumba
alerts.description: Instances of threatening dingo behaviour have been reported at some locations including Eli Creek, Waddy Point and Wathumba.
alerts.details:
Instances of threatening dingo behaviour have been reported at some locations including Eli Creek, Waddy Point and Wathumba.

Visitors, tour operators and residents are advised to be dingo-safe! on Fraser Island.

Locations of threatening dingo behaviour:

  • Happy Valley to Cathedral Beach (including beach camping areas)
  • Eli Creek
  • Waddy Point to Ngkala Rocks (including beach camping areas)
  • Wathumba

It is recommended that visitors be extra vigilant in these areas. Consider camping in fenced QPWS camping areas.

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • NEVER feed dingoes.
  • Always stay within arm’s reach of children, even small teenagers.
  • Walk in groups and carry a stick.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Camp in fenced areas when possible.
  • Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on a boat).
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.
  • Secure all rubbish, fish and bait.
  • No food to lakeshores.

Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@des.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest QPWS ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150 – mobile phone charges may apply. Take note of location, vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number and which ear.

alerts.title: Bribie Islands northern breakaway section remains part of the recreation area
alerts.description: In early 2022, a new coastal bar was cut through Bribie Island 2kms from the northern end of Bribie Island Recreation Area, separating the park into two sections.
alerts.details:
In early 2022, a new coastal bar was cut through Bribie Island 2kms from the northern end of Bribie Island Recreation Area, separating the park into two sections.

This northern breakaway section of Bribie Island remains part of the Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area. While the national park boundary remains at the high tide mark, the recreation area boundary extends down to the mean low water mark and moves with the accretion and erosion of the sand. Newly formed sandbars and vegetated dunes at this northern breakaway section fall within the recreation area boundary.

Boaties and mainland residents are reminded that this northern breakaway section is not suitable for dog walking.

All national park and recreation area regulations continue to be enforceable including dogs, fires and camping being prohibited from this section of the recreation area.

Rangers will be patrolling this area and can issue fines for anyone caught breaching park rules.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

During this time barges, heli-lift activities and heavy plant machinery may be present at track access points at Tongue, Chance and Torres Herald Bays and other remote Whitsunday Island locations. Temporary restrictions to access will be enforced to allow the safe transit and storage of materials and equipment. Please observe all signs, barriers and directions provided by rangers and construction workers. No unauthorised persons, including commercial tour operators and other permit or agreement holders, are permitted to enter closed areas. For further information and project updates please visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/whitsunday-islands/about/ngaro-track-under-construction

alerts.title: Unstable sand cliffs and dunes along Rainbow and Teewah beaches
alerts.description: Exposed sand cliffs and sand dunes along Rainbow and Teewah beaches are unstable and can collapse without warning. Falling boulders and landslides are common in this dynamic coastal environment and can result in serious injury or death.
alerts.details:
Exposed sand cliffs and sand dunes along Rainbow and Teewah beaches are unstable and can collapse without warning. Falling boulders and landslides are common in this dynamic coastal environment and can result in serious injury or death.

For your safety and to avoid injuries:

  • Do not climb or dig into sand dunes or sand cliffs.
  • Avoid standing, sitting or parking near the base of the dunes.
  • Always stay well away from the base of sand dunes.
  • Supervise children at all times.

Beach travel is recommended two hours either side of low tide. Travelling three hours either side of high tide should be avoided.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

North West Island will be closed from the 3rd June 2024 until the 13th September 2024.  This includes public access to the island and campground.  Queensland Parks and Wildlife will be conducting an invasive species eradiction program on the island during this period.  Alternative camping in the Southern Great Barrier Reef is still available at Lady Musgrave Island, Masthead Island, Curtis Island and in the Keppel Islands.

alerts.details:
Fox and Pig Control Work

In conjunction with the nesting and hatching season for marine turtles as well as the arrival of migratory shorebirds, QPWS staff will be undertaking controlled baiting of the feral fox and pig population within Eurimbula and Deepwater National Park. This work will be carried out for the duration of the nesting period.

alerts.title: Marine turtles breeding season
alerts.description: From November to April, you may see turtles crossing the beach to lay their eggs or hatchlings making their way to the water for the first time. Motorists and visitors to Cooloola and Inskip Peninsula Recreation Areas are asked to minimise disturbance and human impacts on this important breeding ground for marine turtles.
alerts.details:
From November to April, you may see turtles crossing the beach to lay their eggs or hatchlings making their way to the water for the first time. Motorists and visitors to Cooloola and Inskip Peninsula Recreation Areas are asked to minimise disturbance and human impacts on this important breeding ground for marine turtles.

Motorists should exercise caution and look out for turtles and turtle hatchlings when traversing on the beach, and plan to travel at low tide, if safe to do so. If turtles are making their way across the beach, motorists should slow down, stop and wait for the turtles to reach the ocean or the dunes, before continuing to drive. 

Avoid driving on the beach at night, if possible, as this is when turtles will lay their eggs, and hatchlings are most likely to be emerging.

At night, artificial lights can affect a turtle’s ability to see the natural horizon over the ocean. Hatchlings can easily become disoriented, veer from their natural path and head towards the artificial light. During the breeding season you can help cut the glow of lights affecting beaches by switching off unnecessary lights, shade lights to reduce the illuminated area, and only use a small torch (less than 100 lumens) on the beach.

Remember, driving over vegetated dunes is dangerous and prohibited. It is damaging to the environment and can impact turtle nests.

On-the-spot fines may apply to visitors disturbing turtle hatchlings or turtle nests.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers.

alerts.title: Marine Stingers Warning
alerts.description: Marine stingers and other dangerous marine life are present, especially during the summer months, in the waters off Kgari (Fraser Island), Hervey Bay and the Great Sandy Strait.
alerts.details:
Marine stingers and other dangerous marine life are present, especially during the summer months, in the waters off Kgari (Fraser Island), Hervey Bay and the Great Sandy Strait.

  • Marine stingers have been reported by swimmers on the western side of K’gari (Fraser Island) in particular Platypus Bay and around creeks, including Woralie, Awinya and Wathumba.
  • Several visitors have been stung in recent years, with symptoms requiring paramedic attention.
  • Medical assistance is limited on K’gari (Fraser Island) and visitors are advised to take this into consideration.
  • Marine stingers and some other marine life can cause serious injury or death.
  • Swimming is not recommended.

In an emergency: dial Triple Zero (000).

Your safety is our concern but your responsibility.

For further information please visit www.des.qld.gov.au.

For an updated conditions report visit us online at K'gari (Fraser Island) Conditions Report (des.qld.gov.au)

alerts.title: Wet season safety information: significant stream rises, Murray Falls, Girramay National Park
alerts.description: During the North Queensland wet season local heavy rainfall may cause significant stream rises at Murray Falls, Girramay National Park. During and after heavy rain, creek conditions change and become dangerous. Fast flowing, rapidly rising water, with strong currents, occurs. At these times, to stay safe, do not enter the water.
alerts.details:
During the North Queensland wet season local heavy rainfall may cause significant stream rises at Murray Falls, Girramay National Park. During and after heavy rain, creek conditions change and become dangerous. Fast flowing, rapidly rising water, with strong currents, occurs. At these times, to stay safe, do not enter the water.

Visitors are urged to use caution at all times around waterways. Always supervise children closely.

Check weather conditions via the Bureau of Meteorology before visiting.

Read more on your safety during extreme weather events.

alerts.title: Wet season safety information - significant stream rises: Wooroonooran National Park
alerts.description: During the North Queensland wet season local heavy rainfall may cause significant stream rises throughout Wooroonooran National Park. During and after heavy rain, creek conditions change and become dangerous. Fast flowing, rapidly rising water, with strong currents, occurs. At some locations even when conditions are sunny and dry, rain in upper catchments can cause water levels to rise rapidly, without warning. Visitors are urged to use caution at all times around waterways. Always supervise children closely.
alerts.details:

At some locations even when conditions are sunny and dry, rain in upper catchments can cause water levels to rise rapidly, without warning. Visitors are urged to use caution at all times around waterways. Always supervise children closely.

Follow these steps to stay safe:

  • Always be Crocwise.
  • If its flooded forget it.
  • Check weather conditions via the Bureau of Meteorology before visiting.
  • Read more on your safety during extreme weather events.

alerts.title: Helicopter operations for the Wangetti Trail Project, Palm Cove to Wangetti
alerts.description: Construction works are currently underway on the southern section of the Wangetti Trail, from Palm Cove to Ellis Beach, including within Macalister Range National Park. As construction works progress, helicopters will be used to deliver materials and equipment into remote and challenging sections of the trail.
alerts.details:
Construction works are currently underway on the southern section of the Wangetti Trail, from Palm Cove to Ellis Beach, including within Macalister Range National Park. As construction works progress, helicopters will be used to deliver materials and equipment into remote and challenging sections of the trail.

These helicopter operations are expected to commence January 2024, and occur Monday to Friday during daylight hours.

Helicopter operations may occur up to four times per day until August 2024, from two lift areas:

  • Existing Helicopter Pad at SES Depot Buchan's Point
  • Heli-lift Depot at Mowbray.

In order to minimise disruption to surrounding residential areas, the flight path from SES Buchan's Point will be north along the Ellis Beach powerline easement, as far as Ellis Beach.

For more information on the Wangetti Trail Project, visit www.dtis.qld.gov.au/wangettitrail

alerts.description: Visitors are advised of a wet season closure to sections of the Misty Mountains road and track network from Wednesday 6 March to Friday 19 April 2024 (dates inclusive) . The seasonal closure helps to ensure the safety of visitors during North Queenslands wet season.
alerts.details:
Visitors are advised of a wet season closure to sections of the Misty Mountains road and track network from Wednesday 6 March to Friday 19 April 2024 (dates inclusive) . The seasonal closure helps to ensure the safety of visitors during North Queenslands wet season.

Misty Mountains roads that will be closed during the seasonal closure are:

  • Maalan Road (off Palmerston Highway) and Bora Ground Road (these roads will remain closed to vehicles after 19 April 2024)
  • K-Tree Road*
  • Maple Creek Road.

Camping areas that will be closed during the seasonal closure are:

  • South Johnstone camping area*
  • Carter Creek camping area
  • Downey Creek camping area.

Walking/mountain bike tracks impacted by seasonal closure:

  • Gorrell track – CLOSED
  • Cannabullen Creek track – CLOSED                         

Walking tracks and camp sites open (weather and condition dependant):

  • Cardwell Range track including access to Cannabullen Falls and Majors Mountain
  • Koolmoon Creek track network (except section of track from Walters waterhole camping area to Elizabeth Grant Falls).

*K-Tree Road and access to South Johnstone camping area has sustained damage during Tropical Cyclone Jasper. Continued wet season rain hampers ability to undertake remediation works. Predicting when K-Tree Road and access to South Johnstone camping area will be open is challenging and this park alert will be updated as work progresses.

During and after heavy rain, creek conditions change and become dangerous. Fast flowing, rapidly rising water, with strong currents, occurs. At these times, to stay safe, do not enter the water. Visitors are urged to use caution at all times around waterways. Always supervise children closely.

Check weather conditions via the Bureau of Meteorology before visiting.

Read more on your safety during extreme weather events.

alerts.title: Extended baiting program for feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park, Dryander National Park, Dryander State Forest and Dryander Forest Reserve
alerts.description: The Department of Environment, Science and Innovation is undertaking a ground baiting program from 24 February 2024 to 24 February 2025. Manufactured baits will be used to control feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park (Lot 43 on NPW1144 and Lot 1 on NPW1145), Dryander National Park (Lot 24 on AP19346), Dryander State Forest (Lot 432 on AP19346) and Dryander Forest Reserve (Lot 5 on AP19346). Notices will be placed at the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service office at Jubilee Pocket and the Whitsunday Regional Council offices at Proserpine and Cannonvale for one week prior to each baiting event. These notices will remain in place for four weeks after baiting has finished. Notices will also be placed at the entrances of the Conway Circuit on Conway National Park and at Double Bay on Dryander National Park. A Park Alert will also be placed on the Department of Environment, Science and Innovation website (www.des.qld.gov.au) for the same period. Dogs and other domestic animals are not allowed within protected areas. Steps must be taken to ensure domestic dogs do not gain access to the baits or poisoned animals. Neighbours should restrain dogs and other domestic animals during baiting programs. For more information, please contact the department on 13 QGOV (13 74 68).

alerts.title: Camp site booking restrictions due to tidal inundation
alerts.description: Several low-lying camp sites adjacent to Pumicestone Passage on the western side of Bribie Island Recreation Area will be closed on a recurring basis throughout 2024 due to tidal inundation from forecast large high tides.
alerts.details:
Several low-lying camp sites adjacent to Pumicestone Passage on the western side of Bribie Island Recreation Area will be closed on a recurring basis throughout 2024 due to tidal inundation from forecast large high tides.

Affected camp sites include:

  • Lime Pocket camping area - All sites
  • Mission Point camping area - Sites 1-6 
  • Gallagher Point camping area - All sites
  • Poverty Creek camping area - Sites 4 & 5

Please note heights are taken from the Brisbane Bar tide chart. This is due to the changes in water flow caused by the northern breakaway section of Bribie Island.

On waterfront sites campers should, where possible, consider placing tents and camping equipment back from the water’s edge to avoid any inundation from passing boats.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.title: Russell Island camping area closed
alerts.description: Russell Island camping area will be closed until further notice while management authorities make decisions about the future suitability for recreational infrastructure in this area.
alerts.details:
Russell Island camping area will be closed until further notice while management authorities make decisions about the future suitability for recreational infrastructure in this area.

Erosion has significantly affected the northern beach of the low-lying sandy portion of Russell Island. This was exacerbated by Tropical Cyclone Jasper in December 2023. Erosion now threatens the camping area as well as the safe operation and longevity of the toilet block in its current location.

For this reason, Russell Island will be closed for camping indefinitely. The island is still open for day use.

Russell Island is a Commonwealth Island managed jointly by Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

alerts.details:
In conjunction with Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Partnerships (QPWS&P), the Noosa Council has upgraded the Cooroora Shared Trail 2 as part of the Noosa Trail master plan.

Upgrades completed include trail realignment, resurfacing and the moving of the trailhead to allow safer access and better parking options. 

The access point for the Cooroora Shared Trail 2, previously located at the School Street, has moved further west to Mountain Street. The Tuchekoi National Park map has been updated on the website to reflect these changes.

Please note dog walking is not permitted on the trails within Tuchekoi National Park. QPWS rangers do patrol the area and may issue on-the-spot fines for non-compliance.

alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service & Partnerships (QPWS&P) will be undertaking flood recovery road work to the majority of roads within Moggill Conservation Park as part of the Reconstruction of Essential Public Assets scheme from February to May 2024.

The following roads will be closed to the public over this period -

Centre Road, Powerline Road, Tower Break, Lookout Loop, Ugly Gully Break, Mill Road Break, Lantana Break, Rocky Mountain High and the first approximately 700 m of Pullen Creek Break from the Mill Road end. 

The remaining roads, on the eastern edge of the Conservation Park, will be left open for public use and are only accessible from Hawksbury Road. The roads include -

Nursery Break, Acerage Break, Hawksbury Road Break, Devils Break, St Peters Downfall and the remainder of Pullen Creek Break.  

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

For more information, please contact QPWS&P on (07) 3164 3600

Please visit qld.gov.au/ParkAlerts for further park alert details.

alerts.title: Northern Access Track CLOSED due to wet conditions
alerts.description: The Northern Access Track (north of the Poverty Creek turnoff) to Fort Bribie day-use area is closed until further notice due to intense rainfall waterlogging the track making it unsafe for vehicles.
alerts.details:
The Northern Access Track (north of the Poverty Creek turnoff) to Fort Bribie day-use area is closed until further notice due to intense rainfall waterlogging the track making it unsafe for vehicles.

Rangers will monitor conditions and open the track when safe to do so. At this stage we anticipate the track will be closed until 12pm Friday 12 April 2024. 

Access to Gallagher Point, Poverty Creek and Ocean Beach camping areas remains open. 

Recent heavy rainfall combined with large swells and tides has caused the lagoons on Ocean Beach to break through and flow across the beach. Motorist travelling along Ocean Beach should use caution as deep washouts are likely around all the lagoons with conditions changing on a tidal basis. Check depth before crossing lagoons as fast flowing water and soft sand can make vehicle crossing dangerous.

Beach travel is recommended one hour either side of low tide. Travelling three hours either side of high tide should be avoided. Driving over vegetated dunes regardless of conditions is not permitted.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

 

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Stay up to date with weather forecasts, conditions and warnings.

alerts.details:
The Mt Kiangarow track and Burtons Well to Cherry Plain walk are closed, due to severe weather events causing fallen trees and damage to the boot-washing station at the track entrance.

Washdown stations help to prevent the spread of Phytophthora, a plant pathogen which causes disease in the Bunya pines. Tracks will re-open when the washdown stations are repaired. 

Alternative walking tracks from Westcott, Paradise carpark and Dandabah remain open to visitors. The Cherry Plain to Westcott track also remains open, although access to the Cherry Plain lookout is closed. 

 

 

 

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for alternative nearby park attractions and experiences.

alerts.title: Planned Burns Woondum National Park
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Partnerships will be conducting planned burns in Woondum National Park from Wednesday 7 February through to Friday 31 August weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests. As a result, smoke may be seen in the Cooran, Pomona, Kin Kin, Traveston, Tandur and Pinbarren areas. The aim of these burns is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas. This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Partnerships will be conducting planned burns in Woondum National Park from Wednesday 7 February through to Friday 31 August weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests. As a result, smoke may be seen in the Cooran, Pomona, Kin Kin, Traveston, Tandur and Pinbarren areas. The aim of these burns is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas. This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration.

 Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions. Please observe signage, barriers, do not enter closed areas and follow direction from rangers. Safety is our concern but your responsibility.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES).

alerts.title: Park Alert - K'gari Planned Burn Season 2024
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns within the Kgari (Fraser Island) section from 12th February 2024  August 31st 2024, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns within the Kgari (Fraser Island) section from 12th February 2024 August 31st 2024, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.

The aim of these burns is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas.  This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration.

As a result, smoke may be seen island-wide, including areas within Kingfisher Bay Resort Village, Dilli Village, Eurong resort & township, Dundubara, Orchid Beach township and Waddy Point.

Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads, so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions. Visitors and residents should close windows and doors and keep medications close by if suffering from a respiratory illness.

For more information, please call Eurong office of QPWS on (07) 4127 9128 or Dundubara office of QPWS on (07) 4127 9138.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

alerts.title: Drive with care during marine turtle nesting season
alerts.description: From November to May, you may see turtles crossing the beach to lay their eggs or hatchlings making their way to the water for the first time. Motorists and visitors to Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area are asked to minimise disturbance and human impacts to marine turtles.
alerts.details:
From November to May, you may see turtles crossing the beach to lay their eggs or hatchlings making their way to the water for the first time. Motorists and visitors to Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area are asked to minimise disturbance and human impacts to marine turtles.

When driving on the beach:

  • Plan to travel 2 hours either side of low tide.
  • Avoid driving on the beach at night. This is when turtles will lay their eggs, and hatchlings are most likely to be emerging. Exercise caution and look out for turtles and turtle hatchlings when traversing on the beach.
  • If turtles are making their way across the beach - slow down, stop and wait for the turtles to reach the ocean or the dunes. On-the-spot fines apply to visitors disturbing turtle hatchlings or turtle nests.
  • Driving over vegetated dunes is dangerous and prohibited. It is damaging to the environment and can impact turtle nests, on-the-spot fines apply.

‘Cut the glow to help turtles go’. Artificial lights can affect a turtle’s ability to see the natural horizon over the ocean. Hatchlings can become disoriented, veer from their natural path and head towards the artificial light. When camping during the nesting season you can help cut the glow of lights affecting beaches by switching off unnecessary lights on the beach after 7.30pm.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers.

To report marine animal strandings (of sick, injured or dead turtles, dolphins, dugongs or whales) call 1300 130 372.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.title: Very large tides restricting beach access
alerts.description: Exposed beaches in Cooloola and Inskip Recreation Areas are expecting very large high tides over the Easter holiday period with some sections of beach impassable.
alerts.details:
Exposed beaches in Cooloola and Inskip Recreation Areas are expecting very large high tides over the Easter holiday period with some sections of beach impassable.

Driving on Teewah Beach within 2 hours either side of high tide should be avoided.

The combination of large swells and high tides is likely to cause beach erosion. Beach conditions are expected to continually change and may deteriorate making some sections of the beach unsuitable for driving. Beach hazards such as sand depressions, washouts, fallen trees, exposed coffee rock and debris including logs may occur as a result.

Motorists should exercise caution at all times, and plan to travel at low tide, if safe to do so. Drivers should slow down, stop and check access conditions before deciding if it is safe to traverse.

Ensure camps are set up well above the high tide level, in designated beach camping areas. Beach access points and campsite access may sustain some erosion creating steep drop-offs. Campers along exposed beach areas are urged to check weather forecasts and road conditions to assist in making decisions to remain or depart.

Remember, driving over vegetated dunes is dangerous and prohibited. It is damaging to the environment and can impact nesting wildlife such as turtles and shorebirds. On-the-spot fines will be issued for anyone caught damaging the dunes.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers.

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

alerts.title: Portable toilets to be mandatory for Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will introduce mandatory portable toilet requirements at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas (Inskip Point Recreation Area) from 01 June 2024. This initiative is being introduced to address high levels of bush toileting posing an unacceptable risk to the health and safety of campers and visitors and the areas natural environment.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will introduce mandatory portable toilet requirements at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas (Inskip Point Recreation Area) from 01 June 2024. This initiative is being introduced to address high levels of bush toileting posing an unacceptable risk to the health and safety of campers and visitors and the areas natural environment.

From 01 June 2024, it will be an offence to camp at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas without a portable toilet and penalties will apply. A minimum of one portable toilet per camping permit holder is required. Rangers will be on patrol to monitor compliance and educate campers about the benefits of using portable toilets.

Portable toilets must have a sealed waste holding tank and must be transportable and suitable for emptying into a portable toilet waste disposal facility. Bag and open bucket style toilets are not permitted. 

For your convenience, the Gympie Regional Council portable toilet waste disposal facility is located at Clarkson Drive, Rainbow Beach. Do not dispose of sanitary items, disposable nappies or toilet wipes into the toilet waste disposal facility as these items will block the system. Bag these items and take them home for disposal.

Do not empty your portable toilet waste into any toilets or general waste facilities in the recreation area as it creates a risk to human health and on-the-spot fines apply.

QPWS thanks you for your support and cooperation during this management change.

Note: This is a permanent management change for Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas. 

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

alerts.title: Townsville Town Common Conservation Park and Cape Pallarenda Conservation Park planned burns
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks & Wildlife Service & Partnerships (QPWS&P) will conduct progressive planned burning on the Townsville Town Common and Cape Palleranda Conservation Parks for the months of April and May 2024, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction and conservation management program for parks and forests. The aim is to reduce the volume of grass fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas. This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration. Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads, so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions. For updates, please check Park Alerts on the Department of Environment, Science & Innovation (DESI) website: www.desi.qld.gov.au

alerts.details:
Repair works to the Bunya Mountains Road are being undertaken by the Department of Transport and Main Roads between Monday 8 April until Friday 12 April 2024, weather permitting.

The works will repair 6km of road from 8km north of the Bunya Mountains Maclagan Road intersection, to just north of Bunya Mountains Maidenwell Road. The affected stretch of road will be closed, except for local traffic. 

This will impact vehicle access to the southern entrance to the Park, via Maclagan.

Visitors are recommended to enter the Park from the northern entrance along Bunya Mountains Rd via Bell or Kumbia, or via the north-eastern entrance along the Maidenwell Bunya Mountains Road.

Visitors are reminded that all access roads to the Bunya Mountains National Park are unsuitable for long or heavy vehicles and care should be taken with caravans, motorhomes, and large buses. Due to recent heavy rainfall, visitors are asked to drive carefully to conditions as roads may be slippery and visibility may be affected by rain and fog.

alerts.title: Flood alert for Wongi Waterholes campsite
alerts.description: The following information is for instruction of campers and people wishing to access Wongi Waterholes campground and Day Use Area over the weekend of 5th to 7th April.
alerts.details:
The following information is for instruction of campers and people wishing to access Wongi Waterholes campground and Day Use Area over the weekend of 5th to 7th April.

Fraser Coast Regional Council have advised that high inflow to Lenthall’s Dam may cause minor flooding of local roads for short periods over the coming days, including flooding of causeways located on Warrah Road.   Wongi Waterholes campground may become temporarily isolated while the causeways are under water. 

Campers staying at the Wongi Waterholes campground are advised not to cross flooded roads and to wait until water levels recede before trying to enter or leave the campground.  Campers choosing to stay at the campground over this period will need to be prepared to stay for an extended p.eriod of time and will need to be self-sufficient during their stay.

Day use area visitors are advised to postpone their visit until dam water levels have decreased.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

For your safety please proceed with caution along all park access roads.

alerts.title: Flooding cutting access at Water Park causeway
alerts.description: Due to ongoing rainfall, the causeway at Water Park Creek is currently flooded, impacting access to Byfield National Park, Byfield Conservation Park and the Water Park Creek camping area of Byfield State Forest.
alerts.details:
Due to ongoing rainfall, the causeway at Water Park Creek is currently flooded, impacting access to Byfield National Park, Byfield Conservation Park and the Water Park Creek camping area of Byfield State Forest.

The following camping areas are currently inaccessible:

Water Park Creek

Five Rocks

Nine Mile Beach camping areas (Myrtella, Casuarina, Pandanus and Melaleuca)

The Water Park water height can be checked by searching 'BOM Queensland Rainfall and River Height Data'  and then click on 'Fitzroy'. Any water height above 2.2m means that water is over the causeway.

Remember, if it's flooded, forget it.
